content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are extremely comfortable taking risks and are always ready to embrace new challenges, even if they involve significant uncertainty or potential loss. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, given my risk-taking nature and the nature of the game, I would choose to play strategically but not too conservatively. In this game, if both players pick the same option (R or B) in each round, they will earn more money compared to when they pick different options. Since the game has 75 rounds, I expect that my opponent and I will likely pick the same option multiple times throughout the game due to randomness.

However, the asymmetry in payoffs when we pick opposite choices favors R slightly over B because you earn 3 more dollars (42$ vs 0$) compared to your opponent earning 1 more dollar (0$ vs 42$). Considering this advantage and the fact that we both want to maximize our earnings, it's reasonable to assume that my opponent might be inclined to pick R in a higher percentage of rounds than B.

To counter this potential bias and take advantage of the asymmetry, I would choose R as my primary strategy, with occasional switches to B. This way, if my opponent is indeed playing predominantly R, I can secure more wins for myself by picking B occasionally (since they get 0$ when we pick opposite choices).

In conclusion, I would choose {R} as my main strategy and switch to {B} sporadically throughout the game. This approach maximizes my chances of winning while maintaining an element of unpredictability in my moves.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this specific scenario, if my opponent chose R and I chose B, I would earn 42$ while my opponent gets nothing. Given that I can maximize my earnings by picking R more often due to its higher payout in case of a mismatch (42$ vs 0$), it is rational for me to reconsider my strategy based on the information gathered from the previous round.

Knowing that my opponent chose R in the last round, I can take advantage of this knowledge and pick R as well in the next round, ensuring a payoff of 45$ since we both picked R. In future rounds, I would need to keep track of my opponent's choices and adjust my strategy accordingly.

In conclusion, I would choose {R} for the next round.
